The Law at Sinai

The giving of the Law at Mount Sinai stands as one of the most solemn moments in the history of God's dealings with humanity. It was more than a set of moral guidelines; it was a direct revelation of God's will, spoken by His own voice, demonstrating His authority, holiness, and love.

God's Law Spoken by His Own Voice

When God descended upon Mount Sinai in thunder, lightning, and a thick cloud (Exodus 19:16–18), He spoke the Ten Commandments directly to the people (Exodus 20:1–17). Ellen White writes in Patriarchs and Prophets, p. 33,

“The law of God, spoken by His own voice, is a transcript of His character.”

The Law as a Revelation of God's Will

Christ summarized the law as love to God and love to man (Matthew 22:37–40). Ellen White adds in Thoughts From the Mount of Blessing, p. 109,

“The law reveals to man his sins, but it provides no remedy.”

The Law’s Binding Authority for All Generations

In Patriarchs and Prophets, p. 305, Ellen White writes,

“The law of God existed before man was created...”

Sinai was a reaffirmation of eternal principles. God’s law remains the standard today (Ecclesiastes 12:13–14; James 2:12).

The Law is God's Perfect Will

The Law at Sinai was more than a historical moment—it was the divine declaration of God’s perfect will. It points us to Christ, who fulfilled the law and empowers us to live it out through His Spirit.
